(b)	the qualifying T1 Capital of the Subsidiary expressed as a percentage of all T1 Capital instruments of that Subsidiary plus the related retained earnings and Share premium accounts.

question: Where an MTF Operator lists Securities offered by an Exempt Offer on its MTF, what trading-participant limits and systems-and-controls measures must the MTF have in place, including any platform-origin restriction and information-access requirement?
gold_answer: An MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF so they can be traded among an unlimited number of Professional Clients, but trading by non-Professional Clients must be capped and controlled. [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f] Specifically, the MTF must restrict trading of the Securities to no more than 200 Persons who are not Professional Clients; in the SOURCE framing, this corresponds to permitting no more than 200 Retail Clients, and only where the MTF Operator has assessed those Retail Clients as having appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f] In addition, the MTF must have effective systems and controls that (i) admit only Securities of Exempt Offers made on its own platform and (ii) identify the Persons to whom the Exempt Offer was made. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] The MTF must also ensure its systems and controls support compliance with MIR rule 3.9.1 on admission to trading, as applicable to the relevant Securities. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] Finally, users must be able to obtain Inside Information, including any Offer documents relevant to the Securities, and the MTF Operator should look to the systems-and-controls description referenced in COBS Rule 8.2.2 when seeking to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading. [#TGT:a957fb33-ff4c-44e4-a2e7-06196b2f6b66] [#SRC:1afc74c9-338e-44c8-8b6b-bba509c5946f]
source_text: In respect of Securities offered by Exempt Offer, whether previously offered through a PFP or not, an MTF Operator may list Exempt Offer Securities on the MTF, enabling such Securities to be traded amongst an unlimited number of Professional Clients and not more than 200 Retail Clients which have been assessed by the MTF Operator to possess appropriate knowledge and experience of the relevant risks, in accordance with Market Infrastructure Rules (MIR) Rule 2.8.3. A description of the systems and controls required to be employed by a MTF Operator that seeks to admit Exempt Offer Securities to trading is set out in Conduct of Business Rules (COBS) Rule 8.2.2.

question: In what admission-related scenarios would the Regulator generally require a Reporting Entity to complete MKT Form 10-1 quarterly, and how do those scenarios align with the specific triggers that make quarterly completion mandatory?
gold_answer: A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis when the Regulator requires it, including where that requirement is imposed as a condition of admission to the Official List. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] The Regulator will generally require this quarterly reporting in admission-related circumstances where the Listed Entity being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test, has less than three years of audited financial statements, or is otherwise considered to need quarterly cash reporting (including where the admission involves a cash-box). [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] Read together, these passages indicate that the “condition of admission” trigger for quarterly MKT Form 10-1 completion can be met in practice by the Regulator’s general approach to admissions that present heightened cash-reporting needs—such as assets-test admissions, shorter audited financial history, or cash-box admissions. [#SRC:ef54c7e6-d860-4e8b-aed8-ddcd2cbacab8] [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75] Separately, quarterly completion is also mandatory if the Regulator classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity, or if the Regulator requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR. [#TGT:67e6fb61-6313-4d10-b3bb-b9b99d81cb75]
source_text: The Regulator will generally require a Reporting Entity to comply with Rule 10.1.3B(1)(i) in circumstances where the Listed Entity with Securities being admitted to the Official List is admitted under the assets eligibility test (see Rule 2.3.16), has less than three years of audited financial statements as prescribed in Rule 2.3.2(1), or is considered by the Regulator, for other reasons, to require quarterly cash reports, such as the admission of a cash-box.
target_text:
A Reporting Entity must complete MKT Form 10-1 on a quarterly basis if the Regulator:
(a)	requires it as a condition of admission to the Official List pursuant to section 52(1)(b) of the FSMR;
(b)	classifies the Reporting Entity as a Mining Exploration Reporting Entity or a Petroleum Exploration Reporting Entity; or
(c)	requires it pursuant to section 84 of the FSMR.

question: If a Mining Reporting Entity’s forecast financial information comes from a Production Target for an operating mine, when can it skip complying with Rule 11.9.2, and what does it still have to put in its Rule 11.9.1 disclosure (especially if the economic assumptions are commercially sensitive)?
gold_answer: A Mining Reporting Entity can avoid having to comply with Rule 11.9.2 for forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) when the forecast is wholly based on Ore Reserves, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources, or on Ore Reserves combined with Measured Mineral Resources and/or Indicated Mineral Resources as long as the Indicated Mineral Resources are not what determines whether the project is viable. [#SRC:bf5c6652-b4c7-4b61-8732-68aed56e52a7] However, where the Mining Reporting Entity is making a disclosure under Rule 11.9.1, it still must include details about the assumptions used to work out the forecast financial information, including all material economic assumptions and all other material assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] If it believes the material economic assumptions are commercially sensitive, it must say they are commercially sensitive and describe the methodology it used to determine those assumptions. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489] It must also include the Production Target the forecast is based on, and that Production Target must be presented with all the information required by Rule 11.8.3. [#TGT:2c78a258-d9f2-4150-9d2c-ba681d8f9489]
source_text:
A disclosure by a Mining Reporting Entity is not required to comply with Rule 11.9.2 where the forecast financial information derived from a Production Target relating to an operating mine(s) is wholly based on:
(1)	Ore Reserves;
(2)	a combination of Ore Reserves and Measured Mineral Resources; or
(3)	a combination of Ore Reserves; and
(a)	Measured Mineral Resources; and/or
(b)	Indicated Mineral Resources, provided that the Indicated Mineral Resources are not the determining factor in project viability.
target_text:
A Mining Reporting Entity’s disclosure pursuant to Rule 11.9.1 must include:
(1)	in relation to the assumptions used to determine the forecast financial information:
(a)	all material economic assumptions employed;
(b)	if the Mining Reporting Entity considers the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive, a statement to that effect and an explanation of the methodology used to determine the material economic assumptions; and
Guidance
A Mining Reporting Entity that considers certain information relating to the material economic assumptions to be commercially sensitive should refer to paragraphs 47-54 of the Guidance on Mining and paragraphs 127 and 128 of the Guidance on Continuous Disclosure.
(c)	all other material assumptions utilised.
(2)	the Production Target from which the forecast financial information is derived (including all the information contained in Rule 11.8.3).

question: When a Prospectus has been filed with the Regulator and is intended to be treated as an “Approved Prospectus” for the purposes of subsection (1), what specific approval action must the Regulator take, and how does that action apply where the Prospectus comprises multiple documents under the Rules-based approval concept?
gold_answer: A filed Prospectus is treated as an “Approved Prospectus” only when the Regulator has taken an affirmative approval step, not merely because it has been filed. Under the Regulations’ framing, a Prospectus qualifies as an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in line with the requirements prescribed in the Rules, and references to a Prospectus in the Regulations are generally to an Approved Prospectus unless context indicates otherwise. [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1] In addition, for the filing to result in an Approved Prospectus for the stated statutory purpose, the Regulator must issue the Applicant a notice that states the Regulator’s approval. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] That notice must cover the Prospectus (or, where applicable, the Supplementary Prospectus). [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] Where the Prospectus consists of multiple documents, the notice must expressly approve all of those multiple documents, aligning the practical evidence of approval (the notice) with the Rules-based approval concept used to define an Approved Prospectus. [#SRC:85f98644-465b-43a9-bb47-cedcdbaaf60e] [#TGT:caf92348-9f78-4a22-b449-0824165b55e1]
source_text:
A Prospectus filed with the Regulator is not an Approved Prospectus for the purposes of section 61(2)(a) of the FSMR unless the Regulator has issued to the Applicant a notice stating its approval:
(a)	of the Prospectus or the Supplementary Prospectus as the case may be; and
(b)	in the case of a Prospectus in (a) comprising multiple documents, of all the multiple documents.
target_text:
For the purposes of subsection ‎(1)—
(a)	a Prospectus is an Approved Prospectus if it is approved by the Regulator in accordance with the requirements prescribed in the Rules; and
(b)	a reference to a Prospectus made by or under these Regulations is a reference to an Approved Prospectus, unless the context requires otherwise.

question: When applying the statement that Guidance is indicative and non-binding, how should a firm classify and treat this particular Guidance that is issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (FSMR) and is intended to be read together with FSMR and multiple FSRA guidance documents and rulebooks? In your answer, distinguish between Guidance issued as notations to the Rules and Guidance issued but not incorporated into the Rules.
gold_answer: A firm should treat this document as “Guidance” that is indicative and non-binding, while also classifying it within the Regulator’s two described forms of Guidance (notations to the Rules versus Guidance not incorporated into the Rules). [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] This particular document is expressly described as Guidance issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (“FSMR”), and it is framed to be read alongside FSMR and a set of FSRA materials (relevant Rulebooks, the Guidance & Policies Manual, and specific guidance on ICOs/digital security offerings, virtual asset activities in ADGM, and the regulatory framework for private financing platforms). [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537] To apply the non-binding characterization correctly, the firm should (i) identify whether the Guidance has been made and issued as notations to the Rules or instead has been issued without being incorporated into the Rules, because both are recognized forms of Guidance. [#TGT:9cba1e46-74c9-4276-9e69-6ed8746e30dd] In doing so, the firm should keep the document’s stated context in view—namely that it is issued under FSMR section 15(2) and is intended to be read in conjunction with FSMR, FSRA Rulebooks, and the listed FSRA guidance documents—so that its indicative content is interpreted consistently across those referenced materials. [#SRC:27924586-ba1b-4566-826f-92cba969d537]
source_text:
INTRODUCTION
This Guidance is issued under section 15(2) of the Financial Services and Markets Regulations 2015 (“FSMR”).  It should be read in conjunction with FSMR, the relevant Rulebooks of the Financial Services Regulatory Authority (“FSRA”), the FSRA’s Guidance & Policies Manual, its ‘Guidance – Regulation of Digital Security Offerings (ICOs) and Virtual Assets under the FSMR’ (“ICO Guidance”),  its ‘Guidance – Regulation of Virtual Asset Activities in ADGM’ (“Virtual Asset Guidance”) , and its ‘Guidance – Regulatory Framework for Private Financing Platforms’.
target_text:
Guidance is indicative and non binding and may comprise—
(a)	Guidance made and issued by the Regulator as notations to the Rules; and
(b)	any Guidance issued by the Regulator which has not been incorporated into the Rules.

question: In a Takeover or Merger where a Listed Entity seeks the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, what written agreements and acceptance thresholds must be in place (including where the transaction is an offer versus a scheme), and how does this interact with the requirement to obtain and submit a holding-lock undertaking within two Business Days after issue?
gold_answer: To obtain the Regulator’s prior written consent to release a holding lock on Restricted Securities, the Listed Entity must align the release request with both the post-issue holding-lock undertaking framework and the specific consent preconditions for a Takeover or Merger. The holding lock is expected to be put in place through an undertaking obtained from an appropriate intermediary (for example, a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD, or another entity the Regulator considers suitable) and submitted to the Regulator within two Business Days after the Restricted Securities are issued; that undertaking must also commit not to release the lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent. [#TGT:6e593960-67c1-4a79-90d0-161055303d76] For consent in a Takeover or Merger, the Regulator will not consent unless the applicable transaction-structure conditions are met. If there is an offer, it must cover all Ordinary Securities (or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all Securities in the same class), and holders of at least half of the non-Restricted Securities to which the offer relates must have accepted. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder must agree in writing that the holding lock is immediately re-imposed for any Securities not acquired under the offer. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd] If conducted by scheme, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity must agree in writing to immediate re-imposition if the Takeover does not take effect. [#SRC:93abeb72-be43-4651-af84-e744d0c36ccd]
source_text:
Regulator’s consent to sale of Restricted Securities in a Takeover or Merger. The Regulator will not provide its consent under Rule 9.6.11 unless, to the extent to which they are applicable, all the following requirements are met:
(1)	where there is an offer for Securities:
(a)	the offer is for all of the Ordinary Securities or, if the Restricted Securities are not Ordinary Securities, all the Securities in the same class as the Restricted Securities;
(b)	holders of at least half of the Securities that are not Restricted Securities, to which the offer relates, have accepted; and
(c)	if the offer is conditional, the offeror and the Security Holder agree in writing that the holding lock (imposed under Rule 9.6.9) be immediately re-imposed for each Security that is not bought by the offeror under the offer; and
(2)	where the offer is to be conducted by way of a ‘scheme’, the Security Holders and the Listed Entity in which the Restricted Securities are held agree in writing that the holding lock imposed under Rule 9.6.9 be immediately re-imposed if the Takeover does not take effect.
target_text: Timing and Enforcement. A Listed Entity must obtain, and submit to the Regulator, within two Business Days after the issue of Restricted Securities, an undertaking from a bank, trustee, custodian, Recognised Body, CSD or other entity deemed suitable by the Regulator, to place a holding lock on the Restricted Securities held by it, and not to release the holding lock without the Regulator’s prior written consent.

question: If an Authorised Person runs an MTF or an OTF, which MIR rulebook sections does it have to follow as if it were a Recognised Body/Recognised Investment Exchange, and when COBS Chapter 8 is being read for Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, what words should it swap in for “Investments” and “Financial Instruments” (including where MIR comes in through COBS Rule 8.2.1)?
gold_answer: If the Authorised Person is an MTF Operator or OTF Operator, it must follow certain MIR rulebook requirements that normally apply to a Recognised Body or Recognised Investment Exchange, but it must read those references as if they refer to the MTF Operator or OTF Operator itself. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] Separately, when interpreting COBS Chapter 8 for the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, it must adjust the meaning of key product terms: references to “Investment(s)” are to be treated as references to “Spot Commodity/Spot Commodities,” and references to “Financial Instrument(s)”—including where those terms appear in MIR text that is brought in via COBS Rule 8.2.1—are to be treated as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity/Accepted Spot Commodities,” as applicable. [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2] The MIR sections the MTF Operator or OTF Operator must comply with under the read-across are MIR 2.6, MIR 2.7.1 and 2.7.2, MIR 2.8, MIR 2.9, MIR 2.11, MIR 3.3, MIR 3.5, MIR 3.6, MIR 3.7, MIR 3.8, MIR 3.10, and MIR 3.11. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] Putting these together means the firm both (i) applies the listed MIR obligations in the correct “as if” capacity and (ii) uses the commodity-based term substitutions when COBS Chapter 8 is the interpretive frame for those specific COBS rules. [#TGT:180edda8-db12-4969-97d5-182435bdf094] [#SRC:27f8e3fb-1055-4605-bb11-0b75eba743c2]
source_text:
For the purposes of Rules 22.7.1 and 22.7.2, the following references in COBS, Chapter 8 should be read as follows:
(a)	references to “Investment” or “Investments” shall be read as references to “Spot Commodity” or “Spot Commodities”, and
(b)	references to “Financial Instrument” or “Financial Instruments” (including those in MIR as incorporated by virtue of COBS Rule 8.2.1) shall be read as references to “Accepted Spot Commodity” or “Accepted Spot Commodities” as applicable.

question: Before an Authorised Person opens a trading account that enables a Retail Client to buy and sell OTC Leveraged Products, what onboarding steps must the Authorised Person complete regarding the risk disclosure statement and the Retail Client’s acknowledgement, and what specific warnings and risk statements must that risk disclosure statement contain (including any stop-loss explanation conditions)?
gold_answer: Before opening a trading account that allows a Retail Client to trade OTC Leveraged Products, the Authorised Person must complete onboarding actions tied to both delivery of a compliant risk disclosure statement and documented client acknowledgement. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The Authorised Person must provide a separate risk disclosure statement as part of onboarding in sufficient time before it carries on any business for that Retail Client, obtain a documented acknowledgement that the Retail Client received and reviewed the statement and understands and accepts the risks, give the Retail Client a duplicate copy of that acknowledgement, and keep a record of the acknowledgement in line with applicable record-keeping requirements. [#SRC:3af19a86-294a-44cc-9abc-df79783033e8] The risk disclosure statement used for this onboarding must include a prominent warning that the Retail Client may lose substantially more than the initial margin posted and must also state, among other points, that it may not cover all risks, that the Retail Client may lose all capital outlay and any unredeemed profits, that losses can accumulate rapidly, that leverage amplifies losses, that loss-mitigation systems (including stop-loss limits) may fail, that slippage can occur, and that most Retail Clients lose money. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955] Where stop-loss orders are relevant, the statement must explain them and clearly indicate whether a stop-loss is “guaranteed,” and if not, that it may not limit losses during highly volatile conditions. [#TGT:0987d811-ce0e-4ab8-93b8-90149e88b955]

question: During an investigation, how may the Investigator obtain relevant information and/or documents on a compulsory versus voluntary basis, and what specific written-notice requirements (including timing, place, and premises access conditions) illustrate the compulsory route?
gold_answer: During an investigation, the Investigator can obtain relevant information and/or documents either compulsorily or voluntarily; the compulsory route is described as being exercised principally through the Investigator’s powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, while the voluntary route is simply obtaining the material on a non-compulsory basis. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4] Where the Investigator proceeds compulsorily, the TARGET text illustrates that this can be done by issuing a written notice to the Person Under Investigation or to any other person, even if that other person is not connected to the Person Under Investigation. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] The written notice may require attendance at an interview at a specified time and place to answer questions, production of specified documents (or documents of a specified description) at a specified time and place, and provision of information or assistance as required. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] It may also require the person to permit entry to their business premises during normal business hours so the Investigator can inspect and copy documents located there, which is another concrete mechanism for obtaining documents compulsorily. [#TGT:ba9deea1-694d-4225-bf79-201773a12046] In contrast, if the Investigator chooses the voluntary basis, the passages indicate only that relevant information and/or documents may be obtained without invoking those compulsory powers. [#SRC:cf20c9eb-d551-42cd-87ce-691b75db72d4]
source_text: Power to require documents or information . During an investigation, the Investigator may obtain relevant information and/or documents either on a compulsory basis, principally through the exercise of its powers under section 206(1)(b) and (c) of FSMR, or on a voluntary basis.

question: For a Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, how should it determine whether it must apply the restriction in APP 7, and how does the carve-out for categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 operate when the entity qualifies under Rule 2.3.15 or meets the Regulator’s profitability/revenue or tangible-asset criteria?
gold_answer: A Listed Entity that has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities is required to apply the restriction in APP 7 (or any other restrictions the Regulator chooses to impose) as the baseline obligation. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] However, when assessing what parts of APP 7 must be applied, the entity must also consider the specific non-application rule for certain APP 7 categories, which can remove the need to apply categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac] In practice, the entity should: (i) confirm it is within scope because it has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities; (ii) start from the requirement to apply APP 7 restrictions (or other restrictions set by the Regulator); and then (iii) test whether it meets any of the qualifying conditions that switch off the listed APP 7 categories. [#SRC:8bfb4441-1b4c-4e2a-a529-07992ed8635f] The categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply if the Listed Entity qualifies for admission to the Official List under Rule 2.3.15, or has a profitability/revenue track record acceptable to the Regulator, or (in the Regulator’s opinion) has tangible assets with readily ascertainable value forming a substantial proportion of total asset value—unless the Regulator decides otherwise. [#TGT:044c2eb2-828b-42a2-8b05-68613aed8eac]
source_text: Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Subject to Rule 9.6.2, a Listed Entity which has issued or intends to issue Restricted Securities, must apply the restriction in APP 7 or such other restrictions as the Regulator, in its discretion, decides.
target_text:
Entry into Restriction Agreements and Application of Restriction. Unless the Regulator decides otherwise, the restrictions in categories 1, 2, 3, 4, 7, 8 and 9 of APP 7 do not apply in relation to a Listed Entity that:
(1)	qualifies for admission to the Official List pursuant to Rule 2.3.15;
(2)	has a track record of profitability or revenue acceptable to the Regulator; or
(3)	in the opinion of the Regulator, has tangible assets with a readily ascertainable value which constitute a substantial proportion of the total value of its assets.

question: For a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2, how do the Captive Insurer’s options (establishing funds or notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund) interact with the Regulator’s residual discretion to direct the establishment of one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for that business or any part of it?
gold_answer: A Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company and carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund under Rule 8.2 has a baseline compliance choice: it must either set up one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds or provide a written notice to the Regulator stating that the Captive Insurer is deemed to be a single Long-Term Insurance Fund. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] However, that choice does not eliminate the Regulator’s ability to require fund establishment, because the Regulator retains residual discretion to direct that a Captive Insurer conducting Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds for its Long-Term Insurance Business or for any part of that business. [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] In practice, this means the Captive Insurer can comply initially by notifying the Regulator that it is deemed a single fund, but the Regulator may still direct the Captive Insurer to establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds (including potentially for only part of the Long-Term Insurance Business). [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7] Accordingly, the Captive Insurer should treat the written-notice route as a permitted default position, while recognizing that the Regulator can override that position by directing the creation of one or more funds for the relevant business scope. [#TGT:510a1a41-dd30-47bf-b331-893b2b70a469] [#SRC:f6bf482b-33ba-4cf1-9375-26e6bfeb7ca7]
source_text:
Residual discretion of the Regulator
Notwithstanding Rule 8.1.1 and 8.1.2, the Regulator may, at its sole discretion, direct that a Captive Insurer which conducts Long-Term Insurance Business establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds in respect of its Long-Term Insurance Business or any part of such business.
target_text:
Captive Insurer not a Cell Company
Where a Captive Insurer that is not a Cell Company carries on Long-Term Insurance Business that, under the provisions of Rule ‎8.2, must be attributed to a Long-Term Insurance Fund, it must either:
(a)	establish one or more Long-Term Insurance Funds; or
(b)	notify the Regulator in writing that the Captive Insurer is deemed to constitute a single Long-Term Insurance Fund.

question: When an Authorised Person conducts periodic stress tests for securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, what specific scope elements must be covered to ensure the tests address both the firm-wide impact in stressed market conditions and the risk that pipeline transactions may not complete, including where securitisation is intended as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person’s periodic stress testing must be structured to cover both (i) the required activity/exposure perimeter and (ii) the stressed-scenario impacts and transaction-completion risks that arise across the firm. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] In scope, the stress tests must relate to the Authorised Person’s securitisation activities and its off balance sheet Exposures, and must also test the future ability to transact securitisation when it is used as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] Within that perimeter, the tests must consider the firm wide impact of securitisation activities and Exposures under stressed market conditions and assess the implications for other sources of risk, so the analysis is not limited to the securitisation book in isolation. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] The stress tests must include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, explicitly reflecting the risk that pipeline transactions may fail to complete in a stressed market scenario. [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97] Together, these elements ensure the stress testing addresses ongoing and prospective securitisation capacity (including CRM/liquidity use) while capturing firm-wide stressed impacts and pipeline execution risk. [#TGT:d430637c-0076-42dd-b3ff-ff739c34e3aa] [#SRC:f5a97111-7275-4609-b7ad-615fcf8e3d97]
source_text: The periodic stress testing in relation to securitisation activities referred to in Rule 4.14.5 should consider the firm wide impact of those activities and Exposures in stressed market conditions and the implications for other sources of risk. Such stress tests should include both existing securitisation Exposures and transactions in the pipeline, as there is a risk of the pipeline transactions not being completed in a stressed market scenario.
target_text: Systems and controls for the use of securitisations. An Authorised Person must conduct periodic stress tests in relation to its securitisation activities and off balance sheet Exposures, including testing of future ability to transact securitisation as a means of CRM or for liquidity purposes.

question: If an Authorised Person is using the FCSA and the Collateral’s risk weight would come out below 20%, what do they do with the Exposure split (collateralised vs uncollateralised) and when can they use 0% or 10% instead of 20% for the collateralised part?
gold_answer: Under the FCSA approach, the Authorised Person must first split the CR Exposure into a collateralised portion and an uncollateralised portion, and then apply risk weights to each portion based on what each portion represents. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] The collateralised portion is measured as the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral, and the uncollateralised portion is the CR Exposure amount minus that latest fair value. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] For Credit RWA purposes, the collateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the Collateral as if it were a direct Exposure to that Collateral, while the uncollateralised portion uses the CRW that applies to the obligor. [#SRC:b8497e84-dc88-476d-8393-4486a082c9bb] If the CRW for the collateralised portion (based on the Collateral) would be less than 20%, the default outcome is that the Authorised Person must apply a 20% CRW to the collateralised portion. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] The Authorised Person may instead apply 0% or 10% only in the listed cases, including qualifying SFTs depending on whether the Counterparty is a core market participant, and certain daily mark-to-market OTC Derivative transactions with no currency mismatch depending on whether the Collateral is cash or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438] A further 0% option exists for certain no-currency-mismatch transactions where the Collateral is specified cash on Deposit or specified 0%-risk-weight government/central bank/PSE exposures and the latest fair value used in the collateralised portion has been discounted by 20%. [#TGT:2d046015-ac18-47c6-9602-153602c0f438]
source_text:
Recognition of eligible financial Collateral under FCSA. Subject to A4.3.28, an Authorised Person which has taken eligible financial Collateral for a CR Exposure and is using the FCSA may recognise the effects of CRM of the eligible financial Collateral as follows:
(a) 	break down the Exposure into -
(i) 	a collateralised portion with E equal to the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral; and
(ii) 	an uncollateralised portion with E equal to the E of the CR Exposure less the latest fair value of the eligible financial Collateral;
and
(b) 	for the purposes of calculating the Credit RWA amount pursuant to Rule 4.8.3, use:
(i) 	for the collateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the eligible financial Collateral as though the Authorised Person had a direct Exposure to that Collateral; and
(ii) 	for the uncollateralised portion, the CRW that is applicable to the obligor.

question: If an Authorised Person has to subtract defined benefit pension fund assets when working out CET1 Capital, how can it lower that subtraction, and what must it do about risk weighting for the assets it uses to lower it?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must deduct defined benefit pension fund assets when it calculates its CET1 Capital, so the starting point is that these pension assets reduce CET1 Capital through a deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd] However, for that defined benefit pension fund asset deduction, the amount deducted can be reduced in two ways: first, by the amount of any associated deferred tax liability that could be extinguished if the pension assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and second, by the amount of pension fund assets that the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use, but only where it has provided adequate advance notification to the Regulator that it intends to use those assets. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] If the Authorised Person uses pension fund assets to reduce the deduction, those assets must then be given a risk weight under Chapter 4 of these Rules, rather than being left without capital treatment. [#SRC:b0259e6e-b58e-4055-96ec-75e630bdaada] This sits alongside the wider list of required CET1 deductions (for example, goodwill and certain deferred tax assets), but the reduction and notification steps described here apply specifically to the defined benefit pension fund asset deduction. [#TGT:07c1a4bc-0a9d-43a2-83b5-5e59dc8356dd]
source_text:
CET1 Deductions - defined benefit pension fund assets. For the purposes of Rule 3.10.7(d), the amount of defined benefit pension fund assets to be deducted from CET1 Capital must be reduced by the following:
(a)	the amount of any associated deferred tax liability which could be extinguished if the assets became impaired or were derecognised under the International Financial Reporting Standards; and
(b)	the amount of assets in the defined benefit pension fund which the Authorised Person has an unrestricted ability to use where the Authorised Person has provided adequate advance notification of its intention to use those assets to the Regulator. Those assets used to reduce the amount to be deducted must receive a risk weight in accordance with Chapter 4 of these Rules.

question: If someone plans to trade a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset, or an Accepted Spot Commodity, when is simply following their own plan not enough to count as insider dealing, and what extra “Inside Information” features would you check for (including for Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives)?
gold_answer: Following a person’s own plan to trade—where they formed the intention to deal before they traded—does not, by itself, amount to contravening section 92(2) (Insider Dealing). [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] To decide whether there is a remaining insider dealing concern, you would then check whether the trade is connected to “Inside Information” as defined for Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities, or Related Instruments that are not Commodity Derivatives. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] Under that definition, the information must be precise and not generally available, it must relate (directly or indirectly) to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers or to the instruments themselves, and it must be the kind of information that would likely have a significant effect on price if it became generally available. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977] So the combined approach is: treat “carrying out of own trading intention” as not automatically triggering the insider dealing contravention, [#SRC:78dea780-e39f-407d-855f-5cb46c1b30d7] but still evaluate whether any relevant non-public, precise, price-significant information about Reporting Entities/Issuers or the instruments is involved, because that is what qualifies as “Inside Information” for these products. [#TGT:ac9dc52d-0e6a-4c83-b170-ffe156109977]
source_text: Carrying out of own trading intention. A person will form an intention to deal in a Financial Instrument, an Accepted Virtual Asset or an Accepted Spot Commodity before doing so. His carrying out of his own intention will not of itself contravene section 92(2) (Insider Dealing).
target_text:
In relation to Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments which are not Commodity Derivatives, Inside Information is information of a Precise nature which—
(a)	is not generally available;
(b)	relates, directly or indirectly, to one or more Reporting Entities or Issuers of the Financial Instruments or to one or more of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets or Accepted Spot Commodities; and
(c)	would, if generally available, be likely to have a significant effect on the price of the Financial Instruments, Accepted Virtual Assets, Accepted Spot Commodities or Related Instruments.

question: If an Authorised Person holds its own capital instruments (or might have to buy them because of a contract), what gets deducted from AT1 Capital versus T2 Capital? Also, when it has a significant investment in a Relevant Entity, how does the five-working-day underwriting exclusion differ between AT1 and T2 deductions?
gold_answer: The deductions depend on whether the calculation is for AT1 Capital or for T2 Capital, and the Authorised Person must apply the matching rule set to the matching instrument type. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab] For AT1 Capital, the Authorised Person must deduct its direct and indirect holdings of its own AT1 Capital instruments, and this includes instruments where it has an actual or contingent obligation to buy because there is an existing contractual obligation. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] For T2 Capital, it must deduct its direct and indirect holdings of its own T2 Capital instruments, including own T2 instruments it could be required to purchase due to existing contractual obligations. [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab] If the Authorised Person has a significant investment in a Relevant Entity, it must deduct its direct and indirect holdings of that entity’s AT1 instruments from AT1 Capital, but it does not deduct underwriting positions held for five working days or fewer. [#SRC:3bd61854-86d4-427f-9af0-54918b0e84c8] In the T2 Capital calculation, it must deduct holdings of that entity’s T2 instruments, excluding underwriting positions held for fewer than five working days. [#TGT:5e7bdc23-7d1f-4fc2-8c33-dca7595021ab]
